results.title: Fire safety
results.brief_description: A summary of some basic fire prevention methods aimed at school children. Advice is given on the best kind of matches to use, what to do in case of a gas leak, how to act in case of a fire - calling the fire department or sounding an alarm - how to treat minor burns etc. The advice is aided by little re-enactments involving children demonstrating the right methods.

results.title: Fire safety
results.brief_description: Comedian Ross Williams gives a light hearted, but informative overview of what to do in different sorts of fires such as; kitchen fires, car fires, house fires, bush fires, and campfires. The programme also looks at effective use of appropriate fire extinguishers, the importance of smoke detectors and evacuataion plans, and general safety with household items. Produced with the assistance of Avalon Airport Rescue and Fire Fighting Services, NSW Mines Rescue Service and Tasmanian Fire Service.

results.title: Fire risks with underground conveyors
results.creator_credit: Data Film Productions, National Coal Board, Jack Chambers and Grahame Tharp
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how fires are caused on mine conveyor belts, how correct pit maintenance can prevent many of these outbreaks and how National Coal Board research is developing devices and materials to reduce these risks. Reference is made in the film to the use of polyvinyl chloride plastic for conveyor belts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Data Film Productions, National Coal Board, Jack Chambers and Grahame Tharp

results.title: Fire protection
results.brief_description: Starts with an old hand pump in action and horse-drawn fire tinder. Then shows various fire retardants - sprinklers, foam and Co2; firemen training - gas masks, resuscitation, safety curtains in cinemas, fire drill in schools.

results.title: Fire prevention in the home
results.brief_description: At a school assembly program during Fire Prevention Week the children are told how they can help prevent fires and each child is given a form to take to their parents to check their home for fire danger. One boy and his father go over their home observing electric outlets, danger spots in the basement and attic, care of matches and use of home-type fire extinguisher. Next day the children report what they have learned.

results.title: Fire over England
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, Pendennis, Erich Pommer and William K. Howard
results.brief_description: Historical drama dealing with England’s struggle against the Spanish Armada. Performances by Vivien Leigh, Laurence Olivier, Flora Robson and an early performance by James Mason. Based on the novel by A.E.W. Mason.

results.title: Fire on Heimaey
results.brief_description: This film shows the eruption on Heimaey Island: the eruption threatened to destroy Iceland’s most important fishing centre. The film also shows how the townspeople halted the devastation.

results.title: Fire of the land (A) [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

results.title: Fire mountain
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Dramatic close-up views of a volcano erupting and rare features associated with volcanic action. Filmed during the eruption of Kilauea, on the island of Hawaii in 1969, this was the second greatest eruption in Hawaii’s history, the fountain height exceeding 1800 feet. The lava cascade was more than twice the height of Niagara Falls.

results.title: Fire making
results.brief_description: What causes fire [fire making] in the forest, fields, laboratory, in primitive tribes: the Paris match of 1805; the Congreve match 1827; the Promethean match 1830; strike-anywhere match, plus the production of modern 1920s matches.
